snippet.title: Boston reflects, revs up for first marathon since last year's bombing
snippet.description: City's determination a year after bombing is on display at Old South Church's "blessing of the runners."

snippet.title: A defense of public education against 'the wolves of Wall Street'
snippet.description: A librarian explains why she is sick of assaults on public schools.

snippet.title: A veteran of Afghanistan struggles to transition from military to civilian life
snippet.description: Transitioning from military to civilian life, and from camaraderie to isolation.

snippet.title: New apartment buildings are geared for millennials
snippet.description: Builders change approach to attract millennials who seek sleek, technologically savvy rentals.

snippet.title: Wars on private taxis and Tesla show transportation ripe for disruption
snippet.description: Whether hailing a cab or buying your own car, finding transportation has gotten controversial.

snippet.title: Admiral Farragut and his flotilla of pigeons
snippet.description: Walking up the motionless escalator into the bright spring morning of Farragut Square last Friday, I knew that I wasn't going to work. Not immediately, anyway. Spring was here. I could sense it. The world has changed with the arrival of sunshine. Women are suddenly flowery runway models again. And men in bright shirts are instantly jackets-off, lithe and prone to short sprints and exuberant arm waves for taxis. That old question — "If you had to choose, would you rather be perfectly lit, or have your own theme music?" On a day like today, you can have it all — slap on the headphones and get out and strut in the sunshine to your own soundtrack. After a winter of barely being able to tell which gender you were standing next to on the station platform, it was refreshing — it felt like being born again. Spring. Yeah, baby.

snippet.title: KFC wants you to make your prom special with a chicken corsage
snippet.description: Plus one tweet U.S. Airways really regrets, pot vending machines, and the real price of Google Glass.

snippet.title: Uber meets local lookalikes in Asia taxi-app wars
snippet.description: Riding on its startup success and flush with fresh capital, taxi-hailing smartphone app Uber is making a big push into Asia. There's a twist, though: Instead of being the game-changing phenomena it was in the U.S., Uber faces a slew of competitors using similar technology.

snippet.title: Town Square | Luxury condos coming to Bethesda
snippet.description: Also construction starts on H Street corridor condos.

snippet.title: 49ers linebacker Aldon Smith arrested at airport
snippet.description: San Francisco 49ers linebacker Aldon Smith was arrested Sunday at Los Angeles International Airport after authorities said he became belligerent during a security screening and threatened that he had a bomb.
